anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: biosynthetic gene cluster from S. lasalocidi contains genes that encode for enzymes that synthesize the quinoxaline group, enzymes that construct the peptide backbone, and genes that encode for proteins with unknown function13.

anns.prefix: One of the functionally uncharacterized proteins is Ecm16, which was postulated to provide self-protection against
anns.postfix: based on the sequence identity (~ 30%) it shares with the prokaryotic UvrA proteins that function in the NER pathway13.

anns.prefix: The main findings of that study are (1) the
anns.postfix: sensitive Escherichia coli K12 becomes echinomycin resistant upon transformation with the ecm16 encoding plasmid, (2) Ecm16 does not require participation of the NER proteins UvrA, UvrB, UvrC, or UvrD to provide echinomycin resistance, (3) Ecm16 does not complement UvrA function, (4) Ecm16’s ATPase activity is essential for its anti-echinomycin activity, (5) Ecm16 binds to double-stranded DNA in a nucleotide sequence independent manner, and (6) Ecm16 binds to echinomycin-containing DNA ~ two-fold more strongly than to echinomycin-free DNA.

anns.prefix: The structure of
anns.postfix: closely resembles that of UvrA, the DNA damage sensor component of the prokaryotic nucleotide excision repair system, but Ecm16 lacks the UvrB-binding domain and its associated zinc-binding module found in UvrA. Mutagenesis study revealed that the insertion domain of Ecm16 is required for DNA binding.

anns.prefix: Furthermore, the specific amino acid sequence of the insertion domain allows
anns.postfix: to distinguish echinomycin-bound DNA from normal DNA and link substrate binding to ATP hydrolysis activity.

anns.prefix: We have previously reported the in vivo and in vitro functional characterization of
The main findings of that study are (1) the echinomycin sensitive Escherichia coli K12 becomes echinomycin resistant upon transformation with the ecm16 encoding plasmid, (2)
anns.postfix: does not require participation of the NER proteins UvrA, UvrB, UvrC, or UvrD to provide echinomycin resistance, (3) Ecm16 does not complement UvrA function, (4) Ecm16’s ATPase activity is essential for its anti-echinomycin activity, (5) Ecm16 binds to double-stranded DNA in a nucleotide sequence independent manner, and (6) Ecm16 binds to echinomycin-containing DNA ~ two-fold more strongly than to echinomycin-free DNA.

anns.postfix: X-ray crystal structure of Ecm16 X-ray crystal structure of Ecm16 We have determined the structure of Ecm16 bound to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) at 2.0 Å resolution (Fig. 1a).

anns.prefix: Our final model consists of the
anns.postfix: homodimer, four ADP, two Mg2+, four Zn2+, and 612 water molecules (Table 2).

anns.prefix: Each protomer of
anns.postfix: contains two ABC ATPase motifs, referred to as nucleotide-binding domain I and II (NBD-I and NBD-II).

anns.prefix: The dimer interface of
anns.postfix: buries ~ 3900 Å2 of surface area and is comprised of residues from the ATP-binding I, signature I, and signature II domains (Supplementary Fig. 2).

anns.prefix: The ventral side of
anns.postfix: features an extended groove that is lined with numerous basic residues (K136, K143, K381, R384, R567, K568, R537, K549, K572, K577) (Supplementary Fig. 3).

anns.prefix: DNA-echinomycin stimulates the ATP hydrolysis activity of
anns.postfix: DNA-echinomycin stimulates the ATP hydrolysis activity of Ecm16 DNA-echinomycin stimulates the ATP hydrolysis activity of Ecm16 We reported previously that the ATP hydrolysis activity of Ecm16 is required to render echinomycin resistance in vivo14.

anns.prefix: Because
anns.postfix: * bound preferentially to echinomycin-containing DNA yet it failed to confer echinomycin resistance, we predicted that Ecm16* could not hydrolyze ATP.

anns.prefix: To test this idea, we measured the ATP hydrolysis activity of
anns.postfix: , Ecm16-ΔID, Ecm16*, and UvrA in the presence of drug-free DNA, echinomycin-bound DNA, fluorescein-modified DNA, and doxorubicin-bound DNA (Supplementary Table 2).

provides resistance against a variety of quinomycin antibiotics Ecm16 provides resistance against a variety of quinomycin antibiotics Ecm16 provides resistance against a variety of quinomycin antibiotics We probed the substrate specificity of Ecm16 by testing whether Ecm16 can provide resistance against other DNA-binding drug molecules—doxorubicin, mitomycin C, daunorubicin, actinomycin D, cisplatin, thiocoraline, quinaldopeptin, and sandramycin.

anns.prefix: The degree of resistance provided by
anns.postfix: was most pronounced at the highest antibiotic concentration tested.

anns.prefix: Cells containing the control vector grew very slowly in the presence of 0.1 µM echinomycin, 4 uM thiocoraline, 6 µM quinaldopeptin, or 2 µM sandramycin making it impossible to determine the doubling time, whereas cells expressing
anns.postfix: had doubling times which were more similar to cells which were not treated with the respective antibiotic (only 1.1- to 1.2-fold longer) (Fig. 3).

anns.prefix: Our result showed that
anns.postfix: is most effective against echinomycin, but it also provides some resistance against other structurally similar quinomycin antibiotics.

anns.prefix: Discussion Discussion Here we report the crystal structure of
anns.postfix: from the echinomycin producer S. lasalocidi.
is a homolog of UvrA, the DNA damage sensor protein from the prokaryotic NER pathway.

anns.prefix: Ecm16 is a homolog of
anns.postfix: , the DNA damage sensor protein from the prokaryotic NER pathway.

anns.prefix: The main structural difference between
anns.postfix: and UvrA is that Ecm16 lacks the UvrB-binding domain and a zinc-binding module which are present in all UvrA structures reported to date (PDB ID: 2R6F, 3PIH, 3UWX, 3UX8, 3ZQJ, 6N9L).

anns.prefix: The main structural difference between Ecm16 and
anns.postfix: is that Ecm16 lacks the UvrB-binding domain and a zinc-binding module which are present in all UvrA structures reported to date (PDB ID: 2R6F, 3PIH, 3UWX, 3UX8, 3ZQJ, 6N9L).

anns.prefix: Another potential structural difference is the conformation of the ~ 100 residue insertion domain, although this remains to be verified since the insertion domain is not visible in the
anns.postfix: crystal structure, presumably because this domain is mobile in the absence of a bound DNA substrate.

anns.prefix: Overall, the three-dimensional structure of
anns.postfix: and UvrA are highly similar.

anns.prefix: Overall, the three-dimensional structure of Ecm16 and
anns.postfix: are highly similar.

anns.prefix: Accordingly,
anns.postfix: and UvrA both display ATPase activity and bind double-stranded DNA14.

anns.prefix: However,
anns.postfix: lacks the UvrB-binding domain and its associated zinc-binding module, suggesting that Ecm16 and UvrA have distinct molecular mechanisms acquired potentially through divergent evolution.

anns.prefix: One of the functionally uncharacterized proteins is Ecm16, which was postulated to provide

anns.prefix: The main findings of that study are (1) the echinomycin sensitive Escherichia coli K12 becomes echinomycin resistant upon transformation with the ecm16 encoding plasmid, (2) Ecm16 does not require participation of the NER proteins UvrA, UvrB, UvrC, or UvrD to provide echinomycin resistance, (3) Ecm16 does not complement UvrA function, (4) Ecm16’s ATPase activity is essential for its
anns.postfix: activity, (5) Ecm16 binds to double-stranded DNA in a nucleotide sequence independent manner, and (6) Ecm16 binds to echinomycin-containing DNA ~ two-fold more strongly than to echinomycin-free DNA.

anns.prefix: Lastly, we have probed the substrate specificity of Ecm16 by challenging ecm16-expressing cells with a series of quinomycin and non-quinomycin DNA targeting

anns.prefix: The main findings of that study are (1) the echinomycin sensitive Escherichia coli K12 becomes echinomycin resistant upon transformation with the
anns.postfix: encoding plasmid, (2) Ecm16 does not require participation of the NER proteins UvrA, UvrB, UvrC, or UvrD to provide echinomycin resistance, (3) Ecm16 does not complement UvrA function, (4) Ecm16’s ATPase activity is essential for its anti-echinomycin activity, (5) Ecm16 binds to double-stranded DNA in a nucleotide sequence independent manner, and (6) Ecm16 binds to echinomycin-containing DNA ~ two-fold more strongly than to echinomycin-free DNA.

anns.prefix: Lastly, we have probed the substrate specificity of Ecm16 by challenging
anns.postfix: cells with a series of quinomycin and non-quinomycin DNA targeting antibiotics.
